qas.question: When was the British empiricism period?
What type of philosopher was Francis Bacon?
What type of philosopher was Descartes?
What type of philosopher was Hobbes?
What type of philosopher was Spinoza?
Who was the exponent of rationalism in the Enlightenment?

plausible_answers.text: early modern philosophy and modern science

qas.question: What was British empiricism originally called?
Who was the founder of rationalism?

context: <b8_0>British<b8_0/> empiricism, though it was not a term used at the time, derives from the <a0_0>17th century<a0_0/> period of <b7_0>early modern philosophy and modern science<b7_0/>. The term became useful in order to describe differences perceived between two of its founders Francis Bacon, described as <a1_0>empiricist<a1_0/>, and <b9_0>René Descartes<b9_0/>, who is described as a <a2_0>rationalist<a2_0/>. Thomas Hobbes and Baruch Spinoza, in the next generation, are often also described as an <a3_0>empiricist<a3_0/> and a <a4_0>rationalist<a4_0/> respectively. John Locke, George Berkeley, and David Hume were the primary exponents of empiricism in the 18th century Enlightenment, with <b6_0>Locke<b6_0/> being the person who is normally known as the founder of <b5_0>empiricism<b5_0/> as such.
